title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

text: OF LOCKE.--All our ideas, sensations, notions, or the things which we
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

text: perceive, by whatsoever names they may be distinguished, are visibly
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: inactive--there is nothing of power or agency included in them. So that
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

text: requisite but a bare observation of our ideas. For, since they and every
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: them but what is perceived: but whoever shall attend to his ideas, whether
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: of sense or reflexion, will not perceive in them any power or activity;
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: there is, therefore, no such thing contained in them. A little
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

text: passiveness and inertness in it, insomuch that it is impossible for an
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: idea to do anything, or, strictly speaking, to be the cause of anything:
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: neither can it be the resemblance or pattern of any active being, as is
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: evident from sect. 8. Whence it plainly follows that extension,
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: figure, and motion cannot be the cause of our sensations. To say,
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: therefore, that these are the effects of powers resulting from the
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: configuration, number, motion, and size of corpuscles, must certainly
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: be false. [Note: Vide sect. cii.]

text: 26. CAUSE OF IDEAS.--We perceive a continual succession of ideas, some are
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: anew excited, others are changed or totally disappear. There is therefore
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: some cause of these ideas, whereon they depend, and which produces and
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: changes them. That this cause cannot be any quality or idea or combination
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: of ideas, is clear from the preceding section. It must therefore be a
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: substance; but it has been shown that there is no corporeal or material
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: substance: it remains therefore that the CAUSE OF IDEAS is an incorporeal
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: active substance or Spirit.

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

text: being--as it perceives ideas it is called the UNDERSTANDING, and as it
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

author: Berkeley, George

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

text: down. In doing of which, if I seem too prolix to those of quick

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

text: DENIED.[Vide sect. lxxxiv.]--I do not argue against the existence of
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: any one thing that we can apprehend either by sense or reflexion.
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: That the things I see with my eyes and touch with my hands do exist,
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: really exist, I make not the least question. The only thing whose
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: substance. And in doing of this there is no damage done to the rest
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

text: of mankind, who, I dare say, will never miss it. The Atheist indeed
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

text: 36. READILY EXPLAINED.--If any man thinks this detracts from the existence
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: or reality of things, he is very far from understanding what has been
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: premised in the plainest terms I could think of. Take here an
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: abstract of what has been said:--There are spiritual substances,
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: minds, or human souls, which will or excite ideas in themselves at
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: pleasure; but these are faint, weak, and unsteady in respect of
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: others they perceive by sense--which, being impressed upon them
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: according to certain rules or laws of nature, speak themselves the
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: effects of a mind more powerful and wise than human spirits. These
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: latter are said to have more REALITY in them than the former:--by
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: which is meant that they are more affecting, orderly, and distinct,
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: and that they are not fictions of the mind perceiving them. And
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: in this sense the sun that I see by day is the real sun, and that which I
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: imagine by night is the idea of the former. In the sense here given of
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: REALITY it is evident that every vegetable, star, mineral, and in general
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: each part of the mundane system, is as much a REAL BEING by our
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: principles as by any other. Whether others mean anything by the term
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: REALITY different from what I do, I entreat them to look into their own
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: thoughts and see.

text: 37. THE PHILOSOPHIC, NOT THE VULGAR SUBSTANCE, TAKEN AWAY.--I will
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: be urged that thus much at least is true, to wit, that we take
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: away all corporeal substances. To this my answer is, that if the word
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: SUBSTANCE be taken in the vulgar sense--for a combination of sensible
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: qualities, such as extension, solidity, weight, and the like--this we
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: cannot be accused of taking away: but if it be taken in a philosophic
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: sense--for the SUPPORT of accidents or QUALITIES WITHOUT THE MIND--then
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: indeed I acknowledge that we take it away, if one may be said to take
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: away that which never had any existence, not even in the imagination.

author: Berkeley, George

text: ideas, and are clothed with ideas. I acknowledge it does so--the word
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: our senses. The hardness or softness, the colour, taste, warmth, figure,
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: or suchlike qualities, which combined together constitute the several
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

text: that perceives them; and this is all that is meant by calling them IDEAS;
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

text: eat and drink and are clad with the immediate objects of sense, which
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

text: 39. THE TERM IDEA PREFERABLE TO THING.--If it be demanded why I make
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: use of the word IDEA, and do not rather in compliance with custom
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: call them THINGS. I answer, I do it for two reasons:--first, because
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: the term THING in contra-distinction to IDEA, is generally supposed
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: to denote somewhat existing without the mind; secondly, because
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: THING has a more comprehensive signification than IDEA, including
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: SPIRIT or thinking things as well as IDEAS. Since therefore the
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: objects of sense exist only in the mind, and are withal thoughtless
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: and inactive, I chose to mark them by the word IDEA, which implies
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
author: Berkeley, George

text: those properties.

author: Berkeley, George

title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

author: Berkeley, George

text: opposite to Scepticism than those we have laid down [Note.], as shall be
title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

text: hereafter clearly shown.
